001package com.telos.loops.transport;
002
003import java.io.IOException;
004import java.util.HashMap;
005import java.util.Map;
006import java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture;
007import okhttp3.Call;
008import okhttp3.Callback;
009import okhttp3.MediaType;
010import okhttp3.OkHttpClient;
011import okhttp3.Request;
012import okhttp3.RequestBody;
013import okhttp3.Response;
014import okhttp3.ResponseBody;
015
016/**
017 * Default HTTP transport implementation using OkHttp.
018 *
019 * <p>This is the default {@link Transport} implementation used by the Loops SDK. It provides
020 * reliable HTTP communication with modern features like HTTP/2 support, connection pooling, and
021 * efficient resource management.
022 *
023 * <h2>Features</h2>
024 *
025 * <ul>
026 *   <li>HTTP/2 and HTTP/1.1 support
027 *   <li>Connection pooling and reuse
028 *   <li>Automatic GZIP compression
029 *   <li>Response caching (when configured)
030 *   <li>Proxy support
031 *   <li>Cookie handling
032 * </ul>
033 *
034 * <h2>Default Usage</h2>
035 *
036 * <p>The SDK automatically uses this transport with a default OkHttp client:
037 *
038 * <pre>{@code
039 * LoopsClient client = LoopsClient.builder()
040 *         .apiKey("your-api-key")
041 *         .build();
042 * // OkHttpTransport is used internally
043 * }</pre>
044 *
045 * <h2>Custom OkHttpClient</h2>
046 *
047 * <p>For advanced use cases, you can create a transport with a customized OkHttpClient:
048 *
049 * <pre>{@code
050 * // Create custom OkHttpClient with timeout configuration
051 * OkHttpClient customClient = new OkHttpClient.Builder()
052 *     .connectTimeout(30, TimeUnit.SECONDS)
053 *     .readTimeout(60, TimeUnit.SECONDS)
054 *     .writeTimeout(60, TimeUnit.SECONDS)
055 *     .build();
056 *
057 * OkHttpTransport transport = new OkHttpTransport(customClient);
058 * // Note: Custom transport injection not yet available in LoopsClient
059 * }</pre>
060 *
061 * <h2>Proxy Configuration</h2>
062 *
063 * <pre>{@code
064 * // Configure HTTP proxy
065 * Proxy proxy = new Proxy(Proxy.Type.HTTP,
066 *     new InetSocketAddress("proxy.example.com", 8080));
067 *
068 * OkHttpClient proxyClient = new OkHttpClient.Builder()
069 *     .proxy(proxy)
070 *     .build();
071 *
072 * OkHttpTransport transport = new OkHttpTransport(proxyClient);
073 * }</pre>
074 *
075 * <h2>Request Logging</h2>
076 *
077 * <pre>{@code
078 * // Add HTTP logging interceptor
079 * HttpLoggingInterceptor logging = new HttpLoggingInterceptor();
080 * logging.setLevel(HttpLoggingInterceptor.Level.BODY);
081 *
082 * OkHttpClient loggingClient = new OkHttpClient.Builder()
083 *     .addInterceptor(logging)
084 *     .build();
085 *
086 * OkHttpTransport transport = new OkHttpTransport(loggingClient);
087 * }</pre>
088 *
089 * <h2>Thread Safety</h2>
090 *
091 * <p>This class is thread-safe and can be used concurrently from multiple threads. The underlying
092 * OkHttpClient manages connection pooling and thread safety internally.
093 *
094 * @see Transport
095 * @see TransportRequest
096 * @see TransportResponse
097 */
098public class OkHttpTransport implements Transport {
099
100  private final OkHttpClient client;
101
102  /**
103   * Creates a new OkHttpTransport with a default OkHttpClient.
104   *
105   * <p>The default client uses OkHttp's default configuration with sensible timeouts and
106   * connection pooling.
107   */
108  public OkHttpTransport() {
109    this(new OkHttpClient());
110  }
111
112  /**
113   * Creates a new OkHttpTransport with a custom OkHttpClient.
114   *
115   * <p>Use this constructor to provide a customized OkHttpClient with specific timeouts, proxy
116   * settings, interceptors, or other configuration.
117   *
118   * @param client the OkHttpClient to use for HTTP communication
119   */
120  public OkHttpTransport(OkHttpClient client) {
121    this.client = client;
122  }
123
124  /**
125   * Executes an HTTP request synchronously using OkHttp.
126   *
127   * <p>This method blocks until the HTTP request completes and a response is received. The
128   * response is automatically closed after reading.
129   *
130   * @param request the HTTP request to execute
131   * @return the HTTP response containing status code, headers, and body
132   * @throws RuntimeException if the request fails due to network error, timeout, or I/O issues
133   */
134  @Override
135  public TransportResponse execute(TransportRequest request) {
136    Request okHttpRequest = buildRequest(request);
137    try (Response response = client.newCall(okHttpRequest).execute()) {
138      return buildResponse(response);
139    } catch (IOException e) {
140      throw new RuntimeException("Failed into execute request", e);
141    }
142  }
143
144  /**
145   * Executes an HTTP request asynchronously using OkHttp.
146   *
147   * <p>This method returns immediately with a {@link CompletableFuture} that will be completed
148   * when the HTTP request finishes. The response is automatically closed after reading.
149   *
150   * <p>The request is executed on OkHttp's internal thread pool. The CompletableFuture is
151   * completed on the same thread that receives the response.
152   *
153   * @param request the HTTP request to execute
154   * @return a CompletableFuture that will complete with the HTTP response, or complete
155   *     exceptionally if the request fails
156   */
157  @Override
158  public CompletableFuture<TransportResponse> executeAsync(TransportRequest request) {
159    CompletableFuture<TransportResponse> future = new CompletableFuture<>();
160    Request okHttpRequest = buildRequest(request);
161
162    client
163        .newCall(okHttpRequest)
164        .enqueue(
165            new Callback() {
166              @Override
167              public void onFailure(Call call, IOException e) {
168                future.completeExceptionally(e);
169              }
170
171              @Override
172              public void onResponse(Call call, Response response) throws IOException {
173                try {
174                  future.complete(buildResponse(response));
175                } catch (Exception e) {
176                  future.completeExceptionally(e);
177                } finally {
178                  response.close();
179                }
180              }
181            });
182
183    return future;
184  }
185
186  private Request buildRequest(TransportRequest request) {
187    Request.Builder builder = new Request.Builder().url(request.url());
188
189    if (request.headers() != null) {
190      request.headers().forEach(builder::header);
191    }
192
193    RequestBody body = null;
194    if (request.body() != null) {
195      MediaType contentType = MediaType.parse("application/json; charset=utf-8");
196      if (request.headers() != null && request.headers().containsKey("Content-Type")) {
197        contentType = MediaType.parse(request.headers().get("Content-Type"));
198      }
199      body = RequestBody.create(request.body(), contentType);
200    }
201
202    switch (request.httpMethod()) {
203      case GET -> builder.get();
204      case POST -> builder.post(body != null ? body : RequestBody.create(new byte[0], null));
205      case PUT -> builder.put(body != null ? body : RequestBody.create(new byte[0], null));
206      case DELETE -> {
207        if (body != null) {
208          builder.delete(body);
209        } else {
210          builder.delete();
211        }
212      }
213    }
214
215    return builder.build();
216  }
217
218  private TransportResponse buildResponse(Response response) throws IOException {
219    Map<String, String> headers = new HashMap<>();
220    for (String name : response.headers().names()) {
221      headers.put(name, response.header(name));
222    }
223
224    byte[] responseBody = new byte[0];
225    ResponseBody body = response.body();
226    if (body != null) {
227      responseBody = body.bytes();
228    }
229
230    return new TransportResponse(response.code(), headers, responseBody);
231  }
232}
